Designing a Spinner to Find Probabilities

In the last Problem, we looked at a bonus prize for the winners of the Gee Whiz Everyone Wins! game. To win the bonus prize each winner drew a block from each of two bags. Each outcome consisted of two events: drawing a block from one bag, then drawing a block from a second bag. This bonus game consisted of two events, which can also be called a compound event.

To find all the outcomes, some students made organized lists like Tevy’s.

Some students used a diagram like Santo’s, called a tree diagram, which is a diagram that uses branches to show the sample space of an event.

In this Problem we will look at a game involving spinners. We will look at both compound and non-compound events.

Spring vacation has arrived! Kaleb thinks he can stay up until 11:00 p.m. every night. His grandparent thinks Kaleb will have more energy for his activities during the vacation if he goes to bed at 9:00 p.m. Kaleb makes the three spinners shown below. He is negotiating with his grandparent to use one of the spinners to determine his bedtime.
Which spinner gives Kevin the best chance of going to bed at 11:00?
